content: The "Stop Infant Mortality And Recidivism Reduction Act of 2016" or the "SIMARRA Act" establishes a pilot program for women incarcerated in Federal prisons to reside with their children born during incarceration. The Act aims to prevent infant mortality among babies born to incarcerated mothers, reduce trauma for pregnant inmates, lower recidivism rates for federally incarcerated women, improve the Federal prison system for women, establish risk and needs assessments for female offenders, and implement a post-sentencing assessment system to address the needs of pregnant offenders and enhance public safety. The Act aims to prevent infant mortality among babies born to incarcerated mothers, reduce trauma for pregnant inmates, lower recidivism rates for federally incarcerated women, improve the Federal prison system for women, establish risk and needs assessments for female offenders, and implement regular outcome evaluations of programs for federally incarcerated pregnant women and mothers to ensure evidence-based interventions. Additionally, it assists the Department of Justice in addressing the cost structure of the Federal prison system to maintain safe prison nurseries without compromising critical missions. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR OF FEDERAL BUREAU OF PRISONS. The Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons consults with various officials and develops a risk assessment system for federally incarcerated pregnant women and mothers. They also create recommendations for recidivism reduction programs and productive activities. The Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons conducts research on best practices for risk assessment tools for federally incarcerated pregnant women and mothers, focusing on dynamic risk factors and recidivism reduction programs. The Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons conducts research on best practices for risk assessment tools and recidivism reduction programs for federally incarcerated pregnant women and mothers, reviewing the system biennially for updates. The Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons conducts research on risk assessment tools and recidivism reduction programs for federally incarcerated pregnant women and mothers. This includes making revisions or updates, holding meetings with relevant individuals, reporting to Congress, consulting stakeholders, and using data based on statistical and empirical evidence. Inmates eligible for the Program must be pregnant and under the custody of the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The Program terms are outlined in Section 6. Inmates eligible for the Program must be pregnant and under the custody of the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The Program allows participation for the inmate's term of imprisonment or 30 months, focusing on child-rearing responsibilities, education, counseling, and compliance with custody decisions. The Program allows pregnant inmates under Federal Bureau of Prisons custody to transfer child support payments for their infant and specify a custodian if their participation ends before release. SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF PARTICIPATION: Inmate's participation ends upon release from prison or if infant fails medical criteria. SEC. 8. CONTINUITY OF CARE: Director ensures health and bonding well-being continuity post-program termination. SEC. 9. REPORTING. SEC. 9. REPORTING. The Director must submit progress reports to Congress every year for 5 years after the Act's enactment and issue a final report within 6 months after the Program's termination. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2021 to implement the Act.
